summary: Dylan O'Donnell, an astrophotography enthusiast, shares his journey and techniques for capturing and processing images of the galaxy Centaurus A.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a white lab coat and a black shirt is seated in a cozy living room, surrounded by bookshelves filled with books and a blue couch with a green pillow. He appears to be engaged in a conversation or presentation, using hand gestures to emphasize his points. The man is identified as Dylan O'Donnell, as indicated by the text overlay in the lower left corner of the screen. Throughout the video, he maintains a relaxed posture, occasionally touching his face or gesturing with his hands. The background remains consistent, with the bookshelves and couch providing a comfortable and intellectual atmosphere. At one point, a small window appears in the upper left corner of the screen, displaying a video of a starry night sky with the text "Centaurus A" and a timestamp, suggesting that the man might be discussing astronomical topics. The overall setting and the man's demeanor create an engaging and informative environment.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker introducing himself and his channel about space photography, noting that he's going to share tips and techniques. He mentions focusing on a specific galaxy, Centaurus A, and describes its unique dark dust lanes seen in high detail. His tone is informative and enthusiastic. The speaker then expresses a desire to gather a lot of data.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a white lab coat and a black shirt is seated in a comfortable living room, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. The room is cozy, with a blue couch and a bookshelf filled with books in the background. On the screen, a video of a celestial event is playing, showing a bright object in space with a timestamp of "2021-05-10 08:20:12 pm" and the text "HD 108927" at the top. The man appears to be explaining or discussing the event, using hand gestures to emphasize his points. The video continues with the man still seated in the same position, maintaining his gestures and expressions as he speaks. The celestial video remains on the screen, and the background remains unchanged, creating a consistent and focused atmosphere for the discussion.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing data gathering for images. He speaks in an informative tone, explaining the concept of getting the best out of available data, citing the analogy of "John West" rejecting certain fish to make the product better. The clip transitions to a brief commercial-like segment with a female speaker responding to the analogy. Back to the male speaker, who continues to talk about astronomy and the desire for the "best out of all the data".

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a white lab coat and a black shirt is seated in a cozy living room, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. The room features a blue couch with a green pillow, a bookshelf filled with books, and a staircase in the background. The man appears to be engaged in a conversation or presentation, using expressive hand movements to emphasize his points. At one point, an image of a group of people dressed in traditional attire, holding hands in a circle on a grassy field, appears in the upper left corner of the screen. The image includes the text "Pixtisicht" in orange, which translates to "Pixtisicht" in English, possibly indicating the name of the event or organization associated with the group. The man continues to speak and gesture, maintaining a focused and animated demeanor throughout the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a speaker explaining that different programs have different image grading techniques that allow you to "measure the quality of each frame" to trim off the best. He mentions using the sub frame selector and states he will show a couple of different methods. He identifies himself as Dylan O'Donnell, and says that you're watching "Star Stuff." This is followed by electronic music.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man in a white lab coat sitting in a room with a blue couch and bookshelves in the background, appearing to be in a conversation or interview. The scene transitions to a close-up of a planet with distinct bands, likely Jupiter, set against a dark space background. The view then shifts to a starry night sky, framed by a red structure, possibly a telescope or observatory. An aerial view of a large radio telescope in a rural area follows, with a person walking nearby. The text "STAR STUFF" appears on the screen, followed by "WITH DYLAN O'DONNELL," indicating the title and host of the segment. The video then shows the man in the lab coat inside a control room, gesturing and speaking, with various equipment and a window showing the telescope in the background. The man continues to speak and gesture, emphasizing points with his hands, in a room with a pinkish hue, likely due to the lighting. The video maintains a focus on the man's interaction with the camera, providing a sense of continuity and engagement with the audience.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a repetitive electronic music track, featuring heavy synth bass and high-pitched, oscillating sounds, creating a tense, energetic mood. This is abruptly interrupted by a male speaker apologizing for nearby loud construction noise, proceeding to mention pointing out something regarding an image train. The music fades further into the background as the speaker continues, with the construction noise becoming more prominent and then seemingly stopping.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a person adjusting a telescope, specifically a Celestron model, in a dimly lit room. The individual's hand is seen manipulating the telescope's components, including a camera attached to the telescope. The camera is connected to the telescope via a cable, and the person appears to be fine-tuning the camera's position. The camera has a red ring around it, and the person's hand is shown adjusting the camera's settings. The video includes text overlays that label parts of the camera, such as "off-axis guide prism," "camera chip," and "image circle," providing educational information about the camera's components. The background is blurred, but it appears to be an indoor setting with some equipment visible. The video focuses on the technical aspects of setting up the telescope and camera, likely for astrophotography or similar purposes.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker describing the 2800 mm focal length of a C11 telescope, stating that he is "zoomed in really far into space". He goes on to describe his image train, the off-axis guider, and the guide camera chip orientation, explaining that the prism won't interfere. He mentions a blank filter draw because he is "using no filter" and capturing the galaxy in its "full broadband spectrum".

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a person's hands adjusting a camera mounted on a telescope, with the camera labeled "QHYCCD." The scene transitions to a wider view of the telescope, showing the "Sky-Watcher ESB-Rh PRO" model, as the person continues to make adjustments. The background reveals a dimly lit room with a white wall and a window, suggesting an indoor setting. The next scene shows a close-up of the telescope's interior, with text on the screen stating "SOME MINOR LEAKS PERSIST..." indicating a minor issue with the equipment. The video then shifts to a view through the telescope, displaying a clear image of the moon against a blue sky, highlighting the telescope's functionality. The final scene shows a computer screen with an image processing software interface, with text overlaying the screen reading "sub frame selector / image grading because less is more," suggesting the process of refining the captured image. The video concludes with a view of the computer screen, emphasizing the importance of image processing in enhancing the quality of astronomical observations.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker discussing a camera and its features, mentioning the "QHY 268M" and emphasizing its quality and performance. He then mentions using a "Skywatcher EQ8RH Pro" mount, highlighting its stability and impact on image processing. He then speaks about image eccentricity. The speaker is enthusiastic and informative in his tone. Background music begins playing, featuring an electronic style with a dreamy, slightly melancholic mood. Key elements of the music include synth melodies and a pulsating bass line. As the music continues, the male speaker is heard again, reflecting on studying computers in high school.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a white lab coat and a black shirt is seated on a blue couch in a cozy living room. He is engaged in a conversation, using hand gestures to emphasize his points. The background features a bookshelf filled with various books, adding a scholarly atmosphere to the setting. The man appears to be explaining something with enthusiasm, as indicated by his expressive hand movements and facial expressions. The room is well-lit, creating a warm and inviting environment. The video captures the man's dynamic interaction, highlighting his gestures and the comfortable setting around him.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker recalling a teacher named Mr. Brown, who claimed that none of the students were using their "CPU to its full potential." He adds that he will refer to Mr. Brown during the video when his CPU is "doing overtime." He then concludes that he thinks Mr. Brown "was clearly an idiot".

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a person interacting with a computer screen displaying an image of a galaxy surrounded by stars. The individual's hand is seen pointing at various parts of the image, indicating areas of interest or explaining features. The screen is divided into multiple windows, including a code editor with lines of text, a file explorer with a list of files, and a color bar at the bottom. The person appears to be engaged in an analysis or presentation, as they gesture towards the galaxy image and the surrounding windows. The environment suggests a workspace or a setting where astronomical data is being examined or processed. The video transitions to a split-screen comparison of two images of the galaxy, labeled "NIGHT 1 VS NIGHT 2 / 'SEEING' DIFFERENCES," highlighting the variations in clarity and detail between the two nights. The final frames show a software interface with tables and data, indicating the person is likely using specialized software for astronomical analysis or image processing. The overall atmosphere is one of focused scientific inquiry, with the person actively engaging with the data and tools at hand.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with one male speaker providing instructions on calibrating images with flats and darks. He then asks if someone named Mr. Brown can see that he's using his CPU. His tone is conversational and instructional. He then states he has "about 140 images" with detail in the dust lanes, but worries about some frames not being as good. The male speaker explains he'll use a "sub-frame selector" to address this. The clip ends with the sound of what seems to be a mouse clicking followed by a background hum.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a computer screen displaying various graphs and data, including a 'LAST HOUR' graph and a 'LAST 7 DAYS' graph, alongside a list of system statistics such as CPU usage, memory usage, and processor load. The scene transitions to a wider view of a computer setup with multiple monitors, showing a starry night sky on one screen and various data tables and graphs on the others. A hand appears, pointing at different parts of the screen, indicating specific data points or trends. The focus then shifts to a detailed view of a graph with fluctuating lines and a bar chart, highlighting the data's variability. The video then shows a view of the night sky from a rooftop, emphasizing the starry backdrop. Returning to the computer screen, the video displays a table with columns labeled 'Shin Weight,' 'Median Mean Dev,' 'Noise Ratio,' 'Stars,' 'Star Residual,' 'FWHM Mean Dev,' 'Eccentricity Dev,' and 'Star Residual Mean.' The scene transitions to a close-up of a different table with similar data, highlighting rows with orange shading. The video concludes with a view of two computer screens side by side, one showing a 'SubframeSelector' window with a list of files and the other displaying a file explorer window with a 'New Folder' dialog box open, indicating the creation of a new folder named 'light.' The overall setting suggests a data analysis or monitoring environment, possibly related to astronomy or astrophotography, with a focus on detailed data visualization and management.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with one male speaker noting that his CPU is spiking and his fans are spinning. He then describes the use of a graph and explains that a weight column is not being used, but that one can add a formula from a certain Discord. He notes that the waiting didn't truly reflect what he wanted to get out of the image, which is to know which stars were in focus the most. He describes changing the measurement table to full width half maximum and discusses the numbers displayed and how they represent focus. He then explains shifting the values to remove certain values and addresses an issue where some nights had high cloud, resulting in low signals, which appeared focused, but actually looked horrible. He then moves on to explaining the use of the stars column and how it allows one to see how many stars PicsInsight was able to count in every frame. He discusses sorting by star count and selecting frames for removal, so that only the best frames remain. Finally, he describes changing the directory for output to move remaining files that weren't deleted to a folder called "Good Subs."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a computer screen displaying a software interface with various settings and options, including a list of files and a preview window showing a starry night sky. The interface is labeled 'SublimeSelector' and 'Sublime Text,' indicating the use of a text editor or file management tool. The scene transitions to a file explorer window on a Mac, showing a directory named 'GOODS' with numerous image files, suggesting the organization of astronomical data. A hand is seen interacting with a device displaying a starry night sky and a red digital counter reading '34400,' likely indicating the number of frames captured or processed. The video then returns to the computer screen, now showing a detailed view of a galaxy with a bright central region and a spiral structure, surrounded by numerous stars. The software interface includes options for adjusting image settings, such as 'Stacking,' 'Alignment,' and 'Calibration,' indicating the processing of astronomical images. The video concludes with a zoomed-in view of the galaxy, highlighting its intricate details and the surrounding stars, emphasizing the clarity and resolution achieved through the software's processing capabilities.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker expressing frustration about a slow process, mentioning copying files. He then jokes about checking the files, saying it will take "a million years" because his CPU is "going crazy." He then thanks his subscribers and references a Super Mario sound effect playing for every 100 new subscribers. He encourages viewers to subscribe for "stupid astronomy comedy". Next, he mentions stacking registered files with drizzle files. He then humorously addresses his CPU by name. There's an excited tone as he describes the final stack image appearing. Following his excitement, a synth-heavy music track begins, creating a feel good vibe. The man comes back in, with a happy exclamation, then describes the picture of the image as sharp. He talks about how the best results come from using the best data and notes he's only using the top 25% of available data, characterizing it as "lucky imaging".

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a mesmerizing view of a galaxy, showcasing its intricate structure and the surrounding stars. The scene transitions to a black screen, followed by a detailed image of the galaxy with vibrant colors and text overlay providing technical details about the imaging process. The text reads: 'Celestron 11" Edge HD @ F10 / 2800mm - $9 x 120s - No Filter - QHY268 Monochrome 41 x 60s - No Filter - QHY247 Colour Total Integration - 1.98 hours from 6 nights of imaging.' This text explains the equipment and settings used to capture the image. The video then returns to the black screen before transitioning to an indoor setting where a person in a white lab coat is seated on a blue couch, gesturing as they speak. The background features a bookshelf filled with books, creating a scholarly atmosphere. The video concludes with the person continuing to speak, maintaining the same indoor setting.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with instrumental music, featuring a light, synth-heavy tune that evokes a dreamy, space-like atmosphere. A male speaker then begins, discussing "space objects". He summarizes the importance of image selection and grading, emphasizing the need for quality over quantity in data. The speaker encourages the audience to discard lower quality data. The music continues softly in the background, underscoring the speaker's closing remarks.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a white lab coat and a black shirt is seated in a comfortable living room, engaging in a conversation or presentation. He is positioned in front of a blue couch adorned with a green pillow, and behind him, a bookshelf filled with various books and items adds to the cozy atmosphere. The man uses expressive hand gestures to emphasize his points, occasionally pointing with his index finger, raising his hand with fingers spread, and giving a thumbs-up. His facial expressions are animated, indicating his enthusiasm and engagement in the discussion. The setting is well-lit, creating a warm and inviting environment, and the man's attire suggests he might be a professional or expert in a particular field. The video captures the man's dynamic communication style, making it an engaging and informative viewing experience.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features one male speaker in a casual tone. He thanks people for their concern about his nose and shares that he visited a skin cancer clinic where a doctor "blasted [his] face with liquid nitrogen" to remove "trouble spots," which turned out to be benign. He then advises the audience to "slip, slop, slap," especially when going out in the sun in the UV capital of Australia because "dying of skin cancer early probably isn't fun."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a person sitting in a room, wearing a white lab coat over a black shirt, gesturing with their hands while speaking. The background features a bookshelf filled with books and a blue couch. Social media handles are displayed on the left side of the screen, including Instagram (@dylan_odonnell_), Twitter (@erfmufn), Facebook (facebook.com/dylanodonnell), and Reddit (reddit.com/user/dylanodonnell). The scene transitions to a night sky filled with stars, with a tree visible on the right side and a white structure in the foreground. The camera captures the star trails, creating circular patterns in the sky. The video then shows the interior of a telescope dome, with the telescope pointing towards the starry sky. The text 'Music For Telescopes' by Dylan O'Donnell appears on the screen, along with icons for various music platforms such as Tidal, Apple Music, iTunes, Amazon, Google Play, and Spotify. The video concludes with a view of the telescope's mechanical parts and the starry sky visible through the dome's opening.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker thanking someone for tagging him in images, and expressing hope that their astrophotography journey is going well. He then introduces himself as Dylan O'Donnell and the show as "Star Stuff," with the reminder that "everything is meaningless and we're all going to die".  Following this introduction, instrumental music starts, featuring electric guitars, bass, and drums, creating a melancholic, indie rock vibe.  No further speech is present during the music.
